byline.contributor: Edward Wong reported from Beijing, Neil Gough from Hong Kong and Alexandra Stevenson from New York. Mia Li and Kiki Zhao contributed research.
byline.original: By EDWARD WONG, NEIL GOUGH and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

abstract: Chinese authorities' aggressive intervention in effort to stem stock market crisis has averted worst effects of plunge but has also raised fears of abuses on part of government; authorities have resorted to arrests, searches and invasive tactics usually reserved for controlling political dissent, contributing to atmosphere of fear and uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: In addition to imposing extraordinary restrictions on the sale of stocks, the authorities have harnessed a security apparatus usually more focused on political dissent.

headline.main: China’s Response to Stock Plunge Rattles Traders
